Definition: Output the result as "Toxic" if the given sentence is rude, disrespectful, or inappropriate otherwise output as "Non-toxic".

Positive Examples.input:

 John Stuart Mill

Comment: I feel many coaches make the game too hard. I realize the size and speed of defenses really affect the offensive game plan. Coaches and players spend hours watching film and looking for cracks where 1/10th of a second makes the difference. Ever since I was a little kid the game always comes down to who blocks and tackles the best. Who can cause turnovers. Who can keep away from stupid penalties and mistakes. It's really pretty basic. Only the strong survive, not only physically but mentally.  I think coaches need to back off and let the players play. Let the QB call the majority of plays. Let the defensive linebackers call the formations. Let the coaches run players in and out keeping them fresh. Once you can establish field position, then open things up and strike when odds are in your favor. Teams need more discipline including the coaches. That's why the Patriots are favored.Denver can beat these guys if they play together and keep focus. This team isn't used to having butts kicked.

Comment: In our culture, blackface is mockery of those with dark skin and African ancestry. In vaudeville, the stock character "Jim Crow" was a disruptive clown in blackface who disrupted "polite" white actors in public places, like hotels, restaurants, trains and ships. Blackface has largely disappeared from our entertainment media, and so a lot of people have forgotten that it is mockery as used by our culture. But, Black people (not "liberals" per se) haven't forgotten and it's not surprising that Black college students are smart and educated enough to be offended. Calling the offense a "liberal elite" phenomenon also implies that "conservative hoi polloi" haven't got the savvy to recognize blackface as mockery; so in effect you are calling those people stupid and crude.

The offense of blackface is to those who are mocked, African Americans, and not directed toward the "liberal elite", toward "elites" or toward "liberals".

Comment: Journalists?  Columnists seem to be much more common than journalists these days. 

When was the last time you read an article that gave full, clear and detailed information, and allowed the reader to form his own opinion?  Even news articles are far more likely to espouse an opinion, and to provide only such information as will support that narrative.  Opinion, no matter how well sourced, is still opinion.  After all, the reader doesn't know what sources the writer has carefully not used.

I am also reminded of a comment that I have heard in many forms over the years - if everything is an urgent, level one, top priority emergency, then nothing is.  Put another way, if everything we read about politicians in general accuses them of being liars or unprincipled self-serving scoundrels, then that becomes normal, and it is unreasonable to expect people to take notice of the latest scandal involving the latest scoundrel.

Comment: What utter garbage! The Globe's editors are showing disgusting authoritarian tendencies with this tripe.

Senators have been appointed to do a job. In order to do this job, they have been given certain powers in full accordance with the constitution of Canada.

If you don't like the manner in which they exercise their powers, that's one thing - just part of the normal grumbling about politics that comes hand-in-hand with any issue. And if you don't like the powers they have, a very simple procedure is open to you: amend the constitution.

But to suggest that they should not exercise the powers with which they were entrusted due to some feeling that the constitution is a flawed document which should be ignored is simply contrary to the democratic process and is the first step to authoritarian rule.

Comment: Obama's 2017 Overall Budget shows:

33% for Social Security, Unemployment and Labor

28% for Medicare and Health

15% for the military.

4% for Veterans

See the pie chart.

What usually happens in these discussions is "Discretionary" spending gets conflated with the Overall budget spending.

Look at the 2nd pie chart for military spending and Social Security spending .

The military is 54% of  "Discretionary" spending but only 15% of Overall spending in Obama's final budget.

Social Security and Medicare only add up to 8% in the "Discretionary"  pie chart but are 61% in the Overall pie chart.  .

It's like comparing the entire basket of apples (Overall spending) to a portion of the basket (Discretionary spending).

Most military spending is 'Discretionary", most Social Security spending is not.

Comment: Raz- I think Mr Trump is worse than a dud but I also think this system allows places which can be ignored by the weight of simple majorities  to keep a voice in our direction as a country. I disagree on so many levels with folks who voted for Mr Trump and hold no real hope he will do much that is useful. I also worry his administration will hurt a lot of Americans. 
That being said, I emphatically ( I am a far left libertarian) disagree with swapping this system for the simple majority idea. The semi-walls it provides against the tyranny of a simple majority are very important. Comment: First, I just have to say I find the criteria by which of some of my comments are accepted or rejected by the Globe to be incomprehensible. It seems extremely arbitrary, and reminds me of what they used to say of the Court of Equity, i.e. that justice in that Court "was as long as the Chancellor's foot". Anyway,  my point was that, understanding decisions in the context of the times they were made, rather than applying the morals of the present, just seems like common sense--unless you expect our ancestors, unlike us, to have been prescient.

Comment: Remember 2 years ago when the Cardinals won the NL Central division with 100 wins beating out the Pirates (98 wins) and Cubs (97 wins).  The Pirates and Cubs had more wins than either of the other 2 NL division winners. I think the 2nd wild card was great for that scenerio however it was a shame one of those great teams only had a 1 game playoff stint. As I recall the reason for the 2nd wild card to was almost force the 2 wild card teams to use their ace in the wild card playoff game so they would go into the next series at a slight disadvantage.  When there was just 1 wild card team, that team often went far into the playoffs because they often had the momentum of playing competitive games through the end of the season while division winners typically rested players after clinching and lost their mojo. Examples- Rockies 2007 got to the WS. Angels 2002 won the WS. Those are the 2 that immediately came to mind but I remember MLB being concerned that wild cards were often advancing far.

Comment: Wow! The title refers to "Dividend Investors" and the article discusses REITs. REITs are much more sensitive to changes in interest rates than are the much broader dividend-growth stocks. REITs are closer to fixed income investments in that tend to raise their distributions relatively slowly (maybe by 3% per year or so) where true dividend-growers will raise their dividends by two to three times that rate. A typical REIT's distribution might double every 24 years or so while a solid dividend-grower's dividend will double in seven to 10 years. Thus the true dividend-grower's share price, because of that much higher rate of increase in its dividend, will typically hold up much bettr in a rising interest rate environment. 
Some factual information:

Comment: It would have made it a little harder to determine the position of the shooter, since a silencer would suppress the muzzle report so the sonic boom of the bullet would dominate (the boom follows the bullet making the source harder to pinpoint even though it is still loud).    It would take experience (eg:  a Veteran) to pinpoint the source of a suppressed weapon.      

In reality the legislation wouldn't make a difference since he could have easily fabricated a suppressor regardless of whether the legislation passed or not.     All a suppressor does is dampen the muzzle report  - so even a kit sold on Amazon (just look up "rifle solvent trap") is readily available and legal to sell (until converted into a suppressor by the buyer).    

The reality for the U.S. is that there are already SO many guns in circulation that even if they were banned outright (which will never happen)- it would take a generation or two before enough were out of circulation to make a difference.

Comment: "Residential schools were barbaric and a stain on Canada's history. But they bore no resemblance to the death camps..."

And you know that, how, exactly?  Others might--have have--debated the point.  If you've got the stomach for it, read Hidden From History, the Canadian Holocaust.  The term holocaust is not used lightly. Much of the book is dedicated to examining the many parallels.  

Back when Lester Pearson was Secretary of State for External Affairs, the UN gave our Nobel Peace prize winner the opportunity to sign off on its definition of genocide.  Pearson declined to sign. The US didn't sign it either, likely for the same reason: the UN's definition, in many ways, described what had happened to Native peoples in both countries. Instead, what Pearson and others did, was coerce the UN into narrowing --changing--the definition. STILL isn't signed to this day.

Can't believe this?  WON'T believe this?  Sure.  It's called Wilful disbelief.  Canada is still working through it.

Comment: Let me give you an example.  At St. Edward's in Newark, California after some 10 years the laity and an exceptionally good priest had recovered--at one Mass out of 9 offered on a Sunday,--the Ordinary Form of the Roman Rite as put forth by the Vatican II council fathers.  

Gregorian chant had pride of place (indeed the priest chanted his prayers and the people chanted their responses; the whole Mass was sung), the use of Latin was preserved (most of the Ordinary, and the introit, gradual, offertory, and communion were Latin), the mass was clearly a sacrifice, and participatio actuosa was the goal.

That priest's successor (from the dying C.PP.S. confraternity) changed the mass from Latin and English to English only within 4 weeks and got rid of the chant within 6 months.  We were back to the Mass Weakland and McManus imposed by subterfuge.  No explanation given.  

In the Extraordinary Form the laity would have had rights!  Not so in the Ordinary Form. Validity is the only standard.

Comment: There is no doubt that as a performance art, a valid Catholic ordination is not a requirement for good preaching or good liturgy. 

The arguments involve beliefs about the divinely established differences between man and woman, the nature of the origin of Holy Orders, and the notion of Christ as the High Priest described in Hebrews of which the earthly priest is the "alter Christus" in the Eucharist's anamnesis of that one perfect Sacrifice.

All three of those beliefs were rejected by the Episcopal Church beginning in the 1970s, by the Lutheran Church of Sweden in the 1960s, and of course by many other Protestant denominations.

Episcopalians who hew to the former beliefs wound up in "continuing churches" or, in rare cases such as the Episcopal Diocese of South Carolina in a diocese which exited the Episcopal Church.

Not all of the Anglican Communion sees eye-to-eye with the Episcopal Church, and as of late 2015 it is under what is effectively a three-year suspension.

Comment: Hey, someone who understands electricity here. Long cables can pick up very high voltages by coupling to a strong electric field; 50kV per square meter obviously induces more current in the conductor proportional to how many meters the cable run is.

The insulation of the cable itself can suffer dielectric breakdown and short against other conductors given a high enough voltage (higher than EMP, IIRC), but the real risk is the stuff attached to the cable, which would receive significant induced currents through the cable. The E1 component of the EMP is too fast for overcurrent protection devices to trip, so there would be damage.

The sensitive chips in the early computers are even more sensitive and far more numerous now. A CPU is nothing but.

Devices without mains connections and with short conductors are less likely to suffer damage than longer ones or those connected to the grid.

*Some* things would survive, but *enough* would fry to knock out most of civilization for months.

Comment: When it comes to the majority of violent crime we have a *sub-culture*, not "culture", of violence problem. Comparatively small concentrations of loosely-associated violent people commit, and suffer, the majority of criminal violence in any given area.

King County did a study of ER visits for gun shots. Most of the victims had criminal records, had been the assailant in their own time, and were likely to re-offend and be arrested (or get shot) again.  Andrew Papachristos did studies in Chicago and Boston, with more ongoing, showing the same tight concentrations of violence between loose, mostly criminal, associates. The CDC just finished a study (yes Virginia, they can still do -valid- research) in Wilmington using epidemiological methods that found the same associations.

We see it here in Anchorage. Shootings and other violent crimes almost uniformly involve people known to each other, people caught up in our own very small sub-culture of crime and violence, as actors or associates.

Comment: Good question, AlexB2.  Another question: will we ever see results?  If so--another question: , what will it actually mean going forward? No answer today, but we can project some possibilities: 

Some police forces will change the way they interview and determine the file category.  This potentially means:
1. Fewer "unfounded" when there should actually be more "unfounded" (for lack of evidence), so a monumental waste of time/energy/money taking cases to already-overworked courts and pointless courtroom emotional devastation--perhaps on both sides. 

2. This will comfort complainants--until they get to court.  

3. More convictions?  (any stats from Philly?) Enough to justify #1?  More convictions more appeals?  Which may mean a SMALLER  percentage of convictions against the rising number of cases. Now, I could be accused of splitting hairs about percentages.  Here's another percentage we do accept: judging a 15% of 20% "unfounded" rate as too high.  Totally subjective conclusion.

Dinner table conversation: 
He (shaking his head): I never thought I'd be able to say it, Alice, but...
She: (Looking worried) What, George?
He: Well...(big sigh)  we're rich!  
She: (Laughing) You're joking.  If not, hand over a few more dollars for food!  
He (Looking at plate): Hey!  This tastes great! 
She: Yeah, I'm magician-of-the-kitchen with ground beef.  We're rich?

He: And those stocks?  Show you after dinner.  Down at the brokers' this morning. Big, big gains.  Same thing, Alice: if I sold now, I'd cover the margin and STILL walk away with a bundle.
She: Do it. 
He: OK...just wait another month or two. Christmas present, huh?

October 15, 1929.

Comment: Just to be clear, "Syriac" does not refer to an ethnic group or to a particular Christian denomination, but rather to the important dialect of Aramaic which became a principal language of Semitic Christians in Late Antiquity. In fact it is shared by Christians belonging to churches from a wide array of confessions, from Monophysites (who historically did not accept the Council of Chalcedon) to Nestorians (who especially objected to the Council of Ephesus). A few groups in communion with Rome use it as a liturgical language, e.g. the Maronites. Originally the dialect of northern Mesopotamia and eastern Anatolia, it is fairly similar to the Jewish Talmudic Aramaic of Babylon, but not so similar to the Palestinian Aramaic of Jesus.

Comment: There are over 1 million pages of Hawaiian language newspapers written during and after the time of the monarchy all the way up to 1949 that were written in the Hawaiian language by Hawaiians.  (ref. www.ulukau.org , www.nupepa.org)There are also manuscripts written by D. Malo, S. Kamakau, Poepoe, Ulumahiemahie, M. Manu, Kepelino, John Papa Iʻi, David Kalakaua, Liliuokalani, Haleole,  and the list goes on and on with these 19th and 20th century writers.  Hawaiian newspapers are also filled with European stories translated into Hawaiian.  There was a rich amount of reading material and there was an incredible interest amongst citizens to take advantage of these mediums of sharing thoughts, ideas, history, and every day happenings.  It is no mistake that most people who live in Hawaii are ignorant to simple facts of the history of Hawaii and its people, but there is an incredible amount of information out there for you to get educated with.  Mahalo.

Comment: I find it fascinating that "health insurance" isn't thought about the same way "flood insurance" or "life insurance" or "auto insurance" is.  Flood insurance pays you back after a flood.  Auto insurance pays you back after an accident or theft.  Life insurance pays when you die.  But health insurance is expected to pay for routine medical expenses rather than catastrophic ones.  My auto policy doesn't pay for oil changes, new tires or tune-ups. My homeowners insurance doesn't pay to have the grass mowed, the roof repaired or a new dishwasher when the old one croaks. Why should health insurance pay for birth control, immunizations or minor illnesses or injuries?  And how did this get to be a right?

Comment: Excellent suggestions Brooks, but perhaps far too logical to make it into the hearts and minds of the people who actually have the power to do something about it!

As to your statement: "resulted in the collection of more than 7,000 firearms for Britain’s defense against potential invasion by Germany (Britain had virtually disarmed itself with a series of gun-control laws enacted between World War I and World War II)" - they may well have enacted such legislation, but the real reason the UK needed as many weapons as it could lay its hands on at that time was due to the simple fact that virtually all its existing weapons had been left behind on the beaches of Dunkirk, during the mad rush to escape France.

Comment: "Sometimes, if the church finds the priest guilty of abuse but he refuses to cooperate with church authorities, there is no recourse but to defrock him. But by consigning him to a monastery, far from children, those authorities can make sure he is never again placed in a situation where he might abuse children. If the priest refuses to accept and abide by the terms set for his being monitored, the church's authorities will reopen the case, send it back to the doctrinal congregation, and he can be defrocked. This is akin to house arrest, and if he violates the terms, he can still be removed from the clerical state."

There are a lot of "ifs" in this statement, both literally and substantively. As a practical matter, bishops are ill equipped to monitor offenders effectively. Monasteries aren't prisons, and the coming and going of every resident are not tracked 24/7. Monasteries don't want to be jailers. It is unreasonable to ask bishops to do what they lack the capacity to do.

Comment: Your figures do not apply anymore.
 Under new rules in 2012 brought in by Harper, the federal govt bumped normal retirement age to 65 years from 60 for anyone entering civil service after Jan. 1, 2013. This has reduced the cost of the amended pension plan by 12 per cent annually.
Also:
By 2018, federal employees who joined government before 2013 now have to contribute 11.65 per cent of their earnings above a certain threshold ($52,500 this year) compared to 8.6 per cent in 2012. The idea is to have their contributions finally match those of government — a 50-50 split, which is the norm for many private sector plans. During the previous Liberal administration the pension ratio had drifted to 28-72 in favour of employees.

Comment: I agree with your point on the need for a diversified and innovative economy, with a focus on local small businesses. However, I think the bigger question is how do we achieve such an economic model?

By my estimation the problem is that the current social welfare system is overly complex and costly to operate this = reduced return on the investment. 

One way or another, this investment has to be made. If you run a small shoe store, your annual sales are directly linked to the capacity of people to buy your shoes. If I'm on a part-time, short-term contract because the shoe factory was exported to Indonesia (or taken by a robot), I'm not going to spend much money on new shoes, or on other discretionary spending for that matter. Your shoe store won't be able to compete with the big box retailer, and everyone loses but the big guys.

The alternative involves consumers entering extreme debt just to stay afloat, which leads to economic uncertainty... your shoe store tanks here, too.

Comment: This statement of "no significant risk" by the OHA  is very premature.  They have not disclosed the testing that was done on Arsenic levels.     They only reported the results from one lab (ARUP)  not Quest, labcorps, etc.    The testing recommended was for acute toxicity levels which are only detectable for a few days after the exposure.    They have not submitted recommendations regarding testing for long term , low level exposure.  The World Health Organization has some information on the risk and distribution of Arsenic (with the long term/ low level exposure model) here:  http://www.who.int/water_sanitation_health/dwq/arsenicun3.pdf

They should probably take a look at that before stating that there is no need for concern.  There is CLEARLY need for concern.  Not panic, but concern.  Concern and evaluation of the issue that will lead to air quality improvement in our beloved city.

Comment: Those who are dissatisfied with the coverage given to any topic in a particular news source are free to supplement their search for coverage in any other news source.

The Star, the CBC, the New York Times, the BBC, the Guardian, the South China Morning Post, Le Monde, Ha'aretz, Die Welt, Der Spiegel, Nature, JAMA, and more...all get their read. I even read "fringe" news sources to see what the fringe is going on about. If what I'm interested in knowing about isn't in one source, I search around.

Complaining about lack of coverage is childish when there's a whole world of coverage out there.

We're all free to stop reading what doesn't satisfy us.

Comment: I own a house in the northeast side of Oahu that is presently rented long term. Comment: 24 of the 27 smallest pop states now ignored, could not be MORE ignored.

2016, 94% of the campaign events were in just 12 states (containing only 30% of the country's population).
2012, more than 99% of presidential campaign attention (ad spending and visits) was invested on voters in just 10 states.
2008, candidates concentrated over 2/3rds of their campaign events and ad money in 6 states, and 98% in 15. 
2004, candidates concentrated over 2/3rds of their money and campaign visits in 5 states; over 80% in 9 states; and over 99% of their money in 16.

Comment: Take them off which caps?  By statute (8 USC 1258), a person must be in lawful nonimmigrant status to change to another status.  Although, theoretically, it could be possible to promulgate regs permitting the issuance of visas domestically, the real problem is that the status prohibits the issuance of visas to persons who are inadmissible.  One of the statutory grounds of inadmissibility is being present in the US without authorization.  This would have to be changed through legislation, not administratively.
I'm not sure what other administrative changes you are proposing.

Comment: Asking a couple of questions in my own self-interest (full disclosure: Type 2 diabetic) ...

1) Would these drop boxes also be appropriate for depleted insulin vials and insulin pens? Somehow, putting those into the trash doesn't strike me as being a good idea.

2) What about disposal of Sharps containers with items such as insulin syringes, pen needles, and lancets? And the answer is not, "Take them to any pharmacy." In my experience, a lot of pharmacies not only won't accept them, they're also hard-pressed to even name a location that will accept them.

Comment: Capitalism is the one system of exchange that is fair. It allows people to choose whether to exchange a product, service or their labor for an agreed upon amount of money, or to say no and walk away from the deal. No coercion is involved or needed, only competing opportunities. No other economic system can make this claim, as they all require setting prices or redistributing wealth based on arbitrary standards enforced by government coercive power, which is both immoral and ineffective as it limits creation of wealth for all involved. Knight does not coerce anyone to work in his factories and pays local market rates or slightly more in exchange for that labor. His factories have improved economic conditions for entire regions. If that is not enough to assuage your self-imposed guilt when buying a pair of Nikes, an iPhone from China, or produce from Mexico, feel free to send whatever difference you think is due directly to those workers. I suspect you never have and never will, Gary.

Comment: Rural communities and hospitals have used med school debt payment successfully for many years to recruit physicians to their towns.  And it is not a "freebie."  They often have to commit to 5+ years of practice to gain the benefit.  And they don't have to "sign for half the going rate" either. They are paid the going rate or more for primary care docs.  Primary care physicians are not paid as well as specialists (to our shame) and the mountain of debt they have to service is scary and daunting.  Their economic stress drives them into specialties when their heart is in primary care.

Show you one that would sign?  I could show you dozens of them.  They were my students in pre-med program and they still remain in touch... wishing they could have followed their dreams; some finding themselves injecting botox into aging faces.

But, we can do it your way....  and get what we've got.  Have you tried to find a primary care doc in this area still accepting patients lately?  Good luck

Comment: I'd be tempted to re-jig it all and instead of a list, say "wholism" is actually the philosophy that binds major Adventist beliefs. 

Wholism is the idea that Christianity was originally rooted in Hebrew culture, in contrast to later Gnostic-Greek ideas that would later distort the rest of Christianity. The Gnostics actually taught that the Hebrew God Yahweh was an evil lesser god, and the material created world evil or flawed. Gnostics were the "anti-Christs" Paul and John were talking about.

Adventism is the most anti-Gnostic denomination today. We affirm the Creator and His Creation as good (Sabbath as memorial), rest as good (through the Sabbath), the human body as a unity (not something for an immortal soul to escape), that human functions are good (hence our health message), and have hope in a physical resurrection and new earth. 

I think a more philosophical or meta-narrative approach would be better to a laundry list that is getting longer by the year.

Comment: http://www.sentencingproject.org/the-facts/#rankings?dataset-option=SIR has different figures, with Alaska in 37th place for incarceration rate in 2015; BJS showed the same ranking in 2013.  Seems pretty unlikely the entire country shifted so far in two years that we've climbed to 15th place.  Perhaps the real lesson here is that it's too easy to claim conclusions are "data-driven" since there is plenty of conflicting data and detailed definitions, caveats, and footnotes limiting validity of some data.  Lawmakers should have taken data presented by the Alaska Justice Commission with a healthy dose of skepticism and asked far more questions before embracing changes to our criminal code so radical that they risk violating our constitution:  "Criminal administration shall be based upon the following: the need for protecting the public, community condemnation of the offender, the rights of victims of crimes, restitution from the offender, and the principle of reformation."

We really need to put climate change at the top of our list of priorities once and for all.

Is there a flaw in my logic here?

Comment: It's frustrating to have Canadian media advising the implementation of US guidelines without noting that here in Canada (as is the case in much of the rest of the world) health authorities advise exclusive breastfeeding with  the introduction of complementary foods beginning at 6 months, with continued breastfeeding for at least 2 years and beyond. The US, with the heavy influence of infant food makers on its regulatory environment and its lower breastfeeding rates in part due to a workforce with virtually no paid parental leave, still suggests introduction of bottles at 4-6 weeks, solids between 4 and 6 months and breastfeeding for a year. News media: find some Canadian experts who are willing to provide clarity for Canadian parents based on OUR guidelines. Regurgitating inferior, marketing-influenced US guidelines creates unnecessary confusion and the further erosion of supports for parents to continue to exclusively breastfeed through to six months.

Comment: Indeed the very proximate air mass ignites and becomes a plasma that expands so rapidly it exceeds the speed of sound, hence a powerful blast wave to accompany the blinding flash you mention. This blast effect can be divided into two very destructive effects: the “P wave” push outward away from the plasma fireball and the sudden rush of a great mass of air back to fill the semi-vacuum generated by the outward push, the so called “Q wave”. Different kinds of targets respond differently, some to P wave, others to Q wave. Exposed human beings for example, composed mostly as they are with water, are very soft P wave responders, thus easily splashed at quite some distance from ground zero. Hardened underground targets (e.g. missile silos) are, by way of contrast, much more resistant to blast overpressures, hence a kill requires much greater warhead delivery vehicle accuracy - - aka a much smaller circular error probable.

Comment: Sea level rise is very real, but it very likely has nothing to do with man-made CO2 emissions.  10 minutes online will show you that the Global Mean Sea Level has been on a nearly constant rise since 1850.

Comment: "Unfortunately, theres no way to actually improve health care when you start from that paradigm."--"Improving healthcare" is misleading.  We have some of the best healthcare facilities and doctors in the world, and EMTALA forbids providers from turning away those seeking treatment.  The real issue is the multi-decade double-digit increases in healthcare costs--which can be resolved quite easily via the enforcement of existing anti-trust and consumer protection legislation, as well as a mandate on price transparency and consent to services.  The fact that our current leaders of both parties are seeking to implement new, money-wasting bureaucracies instead of demanding prosecution of monopolistic practices as allowed by existing law should be evidence enough that they don't want to solve the problem.

Comment: Since 1970s through the mid 1990s I can personally speak to in most instances the State issued P&A orders on drilled dry holes with low potential over the phone. Typical orders were "40 sacks of cement in and out of surface casing with 15 sacks at top of surface casing" for the most part. Occasionally there would be plugs above the Niobrara pumped by Halliburton but that was the exception, not the rule. In many instances the bulk of those bags of dry cement delivered to the rig went home in some one's car to finish a home or ranch project.

Even those "plugged" low potential wells or supposed dry holes will build up gas over the years and there exists the possibility of "an uncontrolled release of gas" at the surface. The collection of soil, air, and groundwater only scratches the surface. Real problems can and do exist downhole and the study as proposed is only a superficial "feel-good" survey that does not reveal the real problems that may exist in the abandoned well bore.

Comment: Your post is incorrect.  The amount of available fresh water in Canada diminishes every day of every year.  There is ample evidence to support my conjecture and nothing to support yours.

BC and Alberta glaciers, which supply fresh water to the majority of western Canadians, are in a decline, many have disappeared and most others are at a point that they can not be recovered.  As well, the aquifers that these rivers supply are rapidly dropping, take the BC Fraser Valley for example. in the 1970's, the aquifer was at 100 feet.  In the 1990's, it dropped to 250 feet.  Today, new weeks have to be drilled to 500 feet.  Look at fracking; all water ( and it is a lot) is contaminated with up to 26 chemicals and then pumped underground, where it will remain untreated forever.

Comment: "And yes I have worked for large companies as well as government for requests like this subpoena. If we ever did what Hillary and her team did we would all be in jail."

I'm afraid you're wrong about that too, which tells me you were not likely in a position of leadership when you dealt with any subpoena requests, but rather one of the low level gophers doing the grunt work. 

Compliance with a subpoena that involves a large volume records request means you have to show that you put a procedure in place that would to the best of your ability find all the in-scope documents within the timeframe. That is what the Clinton team did. But in such large volume cases it is not unusual that the procedure might miss a few, nor is it criminal if it does. Which is why there were no charges. You think a Republican Congress wouldn't have held her in contempt of Congress for non-compliance if they could have? That alone proves you wrong on this point as well.

Comment: You are pretty much correct, but I take exception to the notion that advanced therapies are not needed for 95% of MS patients.  All MS patients can benefit from therapies that halt (and hopefully reverse) the progression of the disease, regardless of whether they have the more rare aggressive forms, or the less aggressive forms.  It is true that in its early stages of development, stem cell therapy currently carries  a lot of risk so it is likely not worth the risk for some patients, but this therapy will likely become safer over time and/or give rise to other new therapies.

And MS isn't really treatable at all.  Symptoms can be managed to some degree (like one treats symptoms of a cold virus), but the degenerative progression generally cannot be halted.

BTW, I'm very familiar with this disease.

Comment: What is the purpose of the "Overtime"                            This Final Rule updates the regulations for determining whether white collar salaried employees are exempt from the Fair Labor Standards Act's minimum wage and overtime pay protections? They are exempt if they are employed in a bona fide executive, administrative, or professional capacity, as those terms are defined in the Department of Labor's regulations at 29 CFR part 541. This exemption from the FLSA is sometimes referred to as the "white collar" or "EAP" exemption.

What is "overtime"?
Unless specifically exempted, employees covered by the FLSA must receive pay for hours worked in excess of 40 in a workweek at a rate not less than one and one-half their regular rates of pay. This is referred to as "overtime" pay.

These are salaried positions not hourly! Maybe we should rein in our misunderstanding of what one is talking about!

Comment: Being a constitutional republic does not mean we should not and cannot guarantee the election of the presidential candidate with the most popular votes. The candidate with the most votes wins in every other election in the country.

Guaranteeing the election of the presidential candidate with the most popular votes and the majority of Electoral College votes (as the National Popular Vote bill would) would not make us ruled by the mob. 

Mob rule is a form of government in which people vote on all policy initiatives directly. 

Popular election of the chief executive does not determine whether a government is a republic or democracy.

Now, If any candidate wins the popular vote in states with 270 electoral votes, there is no reason to think that the Electoral College would prevent that candidate from being elected President of the United States

Comment: The idea that the test scores are the only measure of a schools effectiveness is laughable.  For as soon as you ask why school sports have no testing standards, although the use a large part of the school budget,  you find out how there are different standards for sports that do not include written test.  

A long time ago some schools tried evaluating the students by how well those students did in the world after graduation.  They were concerned with how many graduates were active voters, held jobs, volunteered  in the community, served in the military and had log term marriages.  But the staunch advocates for test results soon rejected those as not important and made the emphases on standardized test the gold mark of excellence. 

I still judge schools as I read the stories of those graduates whose lives reflect the non-tested values we use to consider as citizenship attributes: vote, hold office, volunteer, and give back to the community.

Comment: Animals are not people. A hunter is not convicted of murder, if he shoots a deer. An unwanted animal often suffers if it is allowed to live, even if healthy. A cat once came to my country home in a state of starvation. I managed to feed it and save its life. However, I have also had a female cat that kept producing more and more batches of kittens. It was impossible to provide for them all. I placed the unwanted kittens in a gunny sack containing a stone, tied up the sack, and placed it in a pond so that the kittens would drown. It was a painless death. In another case, to avoid offspring, I shot and killed our mother cat. Often such methods prevent unnecessary suffering of animals. I also shoot and kill porcupines whenever I can. When our dogs go after them, the porcupines slap their tails at the dogs, and the dogs come home with hurtful quills. When we pull out these quills, the dogs suffer considerable pain. Mercy killing is often the best solution to save animals from pain.

Comment: You would like to believe that, but it is pure fantasy. Canada's tax loopholes disproportionately favour the rich. 
Economist David Macdonald  examined the income distribution of benefit for the 64 Canadian personal income tax expenditures for which there is available data. Out of the 64 tax expenditures, 59 of them provide more benefit to the top 50% of income earners than the bottom half, with the largest share going to the richest 10%. The cost of those 59 expenditures totalled $100.5 billion in 2011 alone. 
Says Macdonald: “In essence, there are two federal transfer systems in Canada: one for the poor and middle class and another shadow system for the rich.”

Comment: I don't think there's much anymore. I remember decades ago some products used the 60hz cycle as a internal clock of sorts, but I doubt many current products do anymore.

But the far bigger problem is that while most new products could easily be manufactured to connect to DC power, you're talking about buying a new product to replace the old one. Or significant work to retrofit. In a typical house, your furnace and A/C, major appliances, TVs, lights, garage door opener, sump pump, power tools, kitchen tools, etc etc would all need to be replaced or retrofitted. That's a huge expense. Much easier are the things that have an external transformer (cell phones, laptop, etc) where you'd only have to replace the transformer.  

In the long run, conversion to DC may make sense, but the transition would present huge problems. Each house might need to install a DC-to-AC transformer to run dual for a decade. But even running dual presents a problem because that would mean dual wiring and outlets.

Comment: A visiting scholar to Texas A&M was detained by customs officials in Houston this week while on his way to speak at a symposium in Aggieland, officials said Friday at the conference.
Henry Rousso was flying in from Paris to participate in the Hagler Institute Symposium when he was “mistakenly detained” Wednesday evening upon his arrival, according to Richard Golsan, director of the Melbern G. Glasscock Center for Humanities Research at Texas A&M.

“When he called me with this news two nights ago, he was waiting for customs officials to send him back to Paris as an illegal alien on the first flight out,” said Golsan during his introduction to the session which Rousso was set to participate in.

After learning about the dire situation, Golsan said he immediately called university officials, leading A&M President Michael K. Young to enlist the help of Texas A&M Law School professor and director of the Immigrant Rights Clinic Fatma Marouf.

Comment: It was not just Pierre Trudeau as nine of ten provinces also supported the Charter which was modeled on Diefenbaker's 1960 Canadian Bill of Rights right down to the notwithstanding clause at section 2..  

In fact Pierre Trudeau invoked Section 2 when proclaiming the War Measures Act to deal with the FLQ during the October Crisis.

BTW it was Diefenbaker and his Minster of Immigration that got rid of the racial preferences in Canada's immigration laws  virtually abolishing the “White Canada” immigration policy on 19 January 1962 and opened up the refugee system.  Since the Bill of Rights had rejected discrimination by reason of race, colour, national origin, religion, or sex, the federal government could no longer justify selecting immigrants on the basis of race or national origin.

Comment: Re para 1: You are correct. My view are inconsistent with a parsimonious reading of Newman.

Re para 2: You ought to know I understand transubstantiation, and concur. However, you have completed ducked my distinction between the Aristotelian metaphysics presumed by "transubstantiation," and the earlier neo-platonic philosophy required to understand the Fathers' assertions about the real presence. Plato's and Aristotle's conception of "the real" are markedly different. Doctrine has developed significantly by switching the underlying philosophy used to give meaning to the presence of Christ in the Eucharist. 

Re para 3: And I would broaden you list of where "revelation [is] to be found" by including the full corpus of theology going back at least 3.5K years (surely we agree that revelation is to be found in the OT!). But I would add all of this is our reflection on what the Spirit has been revealing, and that in its totality it contains an unhealthy dose of human error.

Comment: Like littleyoboboy, kiragirl, and Morimoto, my heart goes out to Robert Scott. In all cases, there's the law, and there's discretionary judgment. In this case, the judge was wrong on both counts. In his/her interpretation of the law, Capobianco deserves life in prison with the possibility of parole. Wrong! Capobianco deserves life WITHOUT parole. In his judgment, Scott was out of line and needed to be removed from the courtroom. Wrong! Scott, as the victim's father, should have been allowed to speak his heart and mind. Yes, Scott was out of line and, yes, the defense attorney, Apo, was just doing his job, but this is the grieving father of a daughter and an unborn grandchild who were stabbed to death. In this situation, the judge should have exercised common sense and compassion and tolerated the father's outburst. Robert Scott deserves our empathy, our understanding. He's speaking from the heart for every father in the world.

Comment: My adopted son (bio-grandson) wanted to enlist in the Navy. He did the testing and passed with high marks for every part of the test. He qualified for every position in every branch of the military. His highest scoring was for nuclear and he was even approached by the nuke recruiters. He was ultimately turned down because he had had some counseling between the ages of 4 and 10 to deal with the abuse he endured at the hands of his father and stepmother when he was 2 years old. Despite his counselor writing 4 letters of recommendation to MEPS, he was still denied. He graduated high school with a 3.8 GPA, never drank, never did drugs, never been in trouble, and was not overweight. He was effectively shut out of every branch of the military because they all go through the same MEPS office. Talk about one disappointed kid. His parting remark to the recruiter - "well, at least you can never draft me."

Comment: "Wealthy" is, of course, a qualitative statement. One makes their own decision on something like that. For my evaluations using general numbers of how much all households in WA state make, it starts at $100K/yr and goes up.
"Poverty" is, however, very quantitative, much less a decision of emotion than of facts of life, and what people in poverty struggle with. For me, easily, that number "starts" at $50K and goes down from there. 1/2 of WA state knows that number very well. Less than 10% of teachers make below that amount, but those who do are guaranteed yearly increases and incentive increases to take them out of that range within only a few years. For instance, 80% of teachers move past $50K/yr in their first 4 years of employ.
I actually agree with Inslee with his wish to help new teachers. I disagree with % increases above median wage in WA state, since that's tantamount to 50% of WA state citizens paying for upkeep of $100K+ employees "boats", in analogy.
So, no, I'm not kidding.

Comment: Jesus was a  liberal - he believed in individual autonomy, equality in the eyes of the law, the need for one to actively seek salvation rather than getting it as virtue (clearly un-socialist), and compassion for your fellow citizens. Liberalism = autonomy, free markets, rule of law; else negotiable. 99% of conservatives are still liberals in the broader definition of the word (though DT threatens that). The restorative justice model that some of these advocates are pushing is probably off the mark. Restorative justice is an Indigenous justice model based on the theory that everything in creation is intertwined and if there is an offender in our midst, everyone will be negatively affected unless we can persuade this individual to make amends. The trouble with the CPP is that contributions qualify for a miniscule tax credit going in but are taxed at marginal rates going out, and benefits are syphoned off to previous generations that contributed very little.

 It is apparent to me that what government employers and employees are putting in the plan right now is insufficient to support the benefits that will be paid out because the actuarial assumptions overstate the interest rate, how else does an average employee end up with a pension that would cost $1M to buy as an annuity when they retire, often at 55? Comment: The Alaska Legislature pushed a State Constitutional amendment to allow for limited entry in 1971. Voters passed it with a wide majority in 1972. Governor Egan did sign the law which proceeded from that outcome.
It was considered imperative at the time to deal with the overwhelming number of folks vying for fish. LE made sense. 
As EL Keith remarks it is the acceptance  that  permits are property which can be bought and sold which is biting us in the hiney.
Federal permits have similar issues. An excellent discussion of what problems this has created can be found here:
http://www.aae.wisc.edu/dbromley/pdfs/fisheriesifq.pdf    

This has never been about crony capitalism but current effects have some semblance to that rather nasty critter...

Comment: CuttySark, It's kind of complicated and depends upon your individual circumstances - length of service, etc etc.. I'm not sure that there is an easy way to calculate the proportion of the commuted value that would be transferred into a LIRA other than getting your Retirement Benefit Statement from your employer upon your retirement.

The statement will show several options for life pension guarantee (with varying joint survivor percentages) along with commuted value.

In my case the commuted option was 'A transfer of $xxxxx to a locked-in retirement savings arrangement. The amount of transfer exceeds the maximum tax-sheltered value by $yyyy.. this excess amount will be paid in cash. 
For me the $yyy was $383,822 so one can take a bit tax hit. I took life pension with 75%JS. Fully comfortable that this was the right decision for me.

Comment: Noe: "Hawaii is one of the healthiest states because of longevity and early adoption of health insurance requirements (pre-Obama). Kanaka maoli do not share the 'good health' that other populations in our state have."

These health disparities occur mostly in rural and undeserved communities where Hawaiians are over-represented, where most are Medicaid beneficiaries and members of a MedQuest health plan, but where they still lack adequate access to health care.  Many can't find a participating plan doctor willing and able to care for them. 

The lack of adequate provider networks violates both Federal law and MedQuest contracts, but state officials have turned a blind eye for years and years. 

OHA and others concerned about health disparities should call for monitoring and enforcement of these basic Medicaid health plan network adequacy requirements.

In Hawaii,  these plans get over $2 billion a year and they need to step it up!

Comment: Of course all this assumes that had the children been kept on the reserves they would have maintained their Indian culture and grown up to be healthy well adjusted adults.  We know from recent experience that that is not so.  Since the scoop policy was abandoned over 20 years ago with a new emphasis placed on keeping  orphans within their native communities the circumstances of these children has not improved and in fact it has become arguably much worse. As of 2012 there were some 250,000 children in government care and of these fully 200,000 with native kids.  Think about it; of a group making up only 3% of the country's population it accounted for 80% of all the kids in care i.e. under guardianship or foster care.  In many cases it was single grandmothers that were raising their grandchildren in poverty and filth often surrounded by other relatives addled by drug and alcohol addictions who were as likely to abuse the children as to care for them. Indian culture maybe, desirable not.

Comment: I assume the Church is called to do something with those who don't live by its teachings because Jesus specifically said his followers should leave the 99 behind and seek out the sinner. So the question is not mine, but derives from the gospel: how do we reach out to the great majority of people who engage in practices of which the Church does not approve? And if your response is that we should "educate" them, I hope you'll also deal with the specifics of how you propose to educate the great mass of humankind. To be honest, I've heard that argument many times, but no one has ever come up with a plan to educate the 90%+ of people who engage in unapproved sexual practices. The idea sounds like one of those bad videos about sex they used to show us in 7th grade, which no one took seriously. And that may be the crux of the question: no one takes seriously the Church's antiquated teachings about sexuality -- not because they're antiquated, but because they're wrong.

Comment: The problem with middle/intermediate schools in general is that no adult is responsible for any particular student - unlike elementary school, where each student has a teacher who is responsible for them.  Lacking supervision, children are inclined to test their limits.  The answer is simple (after all, this is what the private schools all do) - keep class sizes smaller through middle/intermediate school and require each student to be actively mentored by a teacher, so that if the child is having any issues - academic, social, etc. - the teacher can reach out to the student and the parents promptly.  Most of all, the parents need to stay involved.

Comment: What's lost on Trudeau and Morneau are the damaging effects of this environment of long-term tax uncertainty that they are fostering. Suggest restoring some tax predictability, then conducting a spending review, and only then re-evaluate whether there is a significant revenue problem to solve.

Comment: Jerry, I think you are misinformed.  When Alaskan's spend thier PFD at a big box retailer, approximately 9.4% of that goes back to the state's coffers as corporate income tax.  That's not to mention the number of dollars the store's employees pump back into the AK economy by spending their wages here.  Plus many of the big ticket item shops are locally-owned.  

Those local stores are going to be crushed by Walker's move because they have to order their expensive inventory months in advance and had good reason to account on the PFD being two grand.  Now they are stuck with that inventory but it's not unreasonable to expect that their  sales will be at least half of what they projected.  I do not disagree with Walker that something had to be done, but the reserve accounts would have help for at least another year.  Walker could have phased in the 50% cut as a two step process over two years and avoided driving local tax-generating companies out of business.

Comment: Obamacare has not failed. Millions have access to health insurance (and care) that did not have it before. It's a fiscally responsible bill that balances the budget. Yes, some people in higher income brackets have had to pay more than they used to..but those income brackets are quite high, the policies folks now have are better and include preventive care. ACA also provides flexibility for people between jobs and/or running their own small businesses, and the other inevitable bumps and curves most people encounter at various times in their lives. It's predictable, it's stable, and it's working.

Comment: My own daughter has a friend like this. She was sweet and polite, her parents were chaotic and often worrying. 

This friendship was fantastic until high school. I think we were a 'good influence' on the friend. She often stayed over, came on vacation with us and we gave her stability. But, now they are in high school, the friend is constantly on Facebook writing some really worrying posts. She suddenly (at 13) has an older, serious boyfriend. She drove past the other day in a car that left a weed-stink in its wake.

I suddenly realized that I was kidding myself that we would have an influence on her anymore. Now, I worry that she's going to draw my own, fairly naive daughter into all that stuff about 5 years before she'd be comfortable. I've stopped inviting this girl over now bit by bit and hoping the friendship will go on ice. I'm not going to ban my daughter from seeing her.

So Poster, I'd say encourage the friendship while they are young, but watch out when they are teens.

In Vancouver, what happened was very simple: The price of houses COMPLETELY, and FOR THE FIRST TIME EVER, decoupled and detached from the local job market, completely separated away from local incomes.

What caused that in Vancouver? It was simply a massive flood of overseas money arriving, buying up house after house and pushing prices to dozens of times the average annual income.

Comment: The thing about political polls is that they are, at best, an educated guess, and if you make enough guesses sooner or later some of them are going to be correct even if they seem like outliers.

Straight-up polling doesn't necessarily work for politics and election because it is subject to all kinds of systematic error.  Some of this shows up as sampling errors (ie the people who answer the phone call for your survey are not representative of the population as a whole) while other times it is simply a reporting bias (ie supporters of Marine Le Pen might be more likely than supports of Emmanuel Macron to say they are "undecided voters" because she is a controversial candidate).

The end result is that you can't apply standard statistics so any numbers are, at best, a guess.

What does that mean for France?  Who knows.  Mr. Marcron seems like the sensible choice to most but he, much like Hillary Clinton in the U.S., represents the status quo that so many are frustrated with.

Comment: When she was 13,my daughter had surgery to remove a bone tumor coupled with a bone graft. She was prescribed an opioid for pain control. She took one in the hospital and when it wore off she told me that there was no way she was taking another one and just requested Tylenol or Motrin if she started hurting.

My son had his wisdom teeth out and was given a prescription for pain meds. He told me "Mom, don't even bother getting the script filled because I'm not taking them." He also just took a Tylenol or Motrin and that was it.

I taught my kids from a young age that anything that can happen to anyone else can happen to them and that they are not immune from the bad things in this world. I told them the best way to not get addicted to a drug is to never start taking it. The best way not to get a DUI is to not drink or do drugs and drive. I did my best to teach them to think for themselves and make good decisions.

Nothing but respect for these grandparents and guardians who stepped up.

Comment: "Teaching driving has been left up to parents"

That depends on the age of the student.

This past June, my eldest got his instruction permit right after his 15th birthday, since he, his mother, and I want him to get his license as soon as possible. By law, he has to have:
* 30-hour classroom instruction
* 6-hour certified training
* Currently working on (and logging) 50 hours of practice

The 30-hour classroom instruction was required to get his permit before age 15.5 years. The 6-hour behind-the-wheel training will be required to get his license before age 16.5 years.

If we'd waited 6 months, the 30-hour requirement would've been reduced to 4 hours. Then, since he couldn't get his license until age 16.5 (if under age 18, you have to have a permit for at least 12 months), the 6-hour certified training would've gone away.

The 50 hours of practice, logged and signed by a parent, are required to get a license before age 18.

Comment: Robin Brena has a plan
https://www.adn.com/opinions/2016/10/01/alaska-needs-to-reclaim-its-fair-share-of-oil-revenue/


(1) Increase the base rate for the major legacy fields and for merely harvesting our resources rather than exploring for additional resource.

(2) Eliminate credits (taken as deductions and paid) for all but the most challenged fields.

(3) Eliminate loss carryforwards.

(4) Eliminate the "new oil" definition or reduce the scope of its application to only the most challenged fields (which would not include Point Thomson).

(5) Increase progressivity.

(6) Add the auditing and legal resources necessary to ensure revenue certainty for the state and producers and to minimize gaming.

(7) Increase transparency so we know the financial performance of the producers operating in Alaska.

Comment: William, I read a number of conservative columnists every day. I get the National Review. I have looked at Trump's web site. None of that tells me anything about what conservatives really want other than concerns about money.

1. Prosperity comes from your ability to earn a living AND government benefits. If there were absolute anarchy, no one could make a living. If there were no roads and bridges ... ETC.

2. Government regulations cost money, but they also save money in other instances. What if we all had to purchase lab equipment to check the milk we buy? What would it cost us?

3. More taxes do not necessarily mean less money in your pocket. See #2 above. To see only the cost of taxes is an unbalanced, unreal view of things. Taxes can also save money or provide necessary tools to make a living; education, for example.

If the conservative view is simply to harp on the cost of taxes and ignore the other side of the coin, then it is not a useful approach.

Comment: Mr Albertson, you didn't mention what brand of coffee maker you did your research on.  If you dig a little deeper I'm certain you will find that the Canadian version of this coffee maker is either more expensive or missing features.  There is no ethical dilemma in this scenario, companies manufacture different products for different countries everyday that essentially do the same thing, there are just different regional considerations.  Canadians get a five year warranty because they pay for it, not because of an ethical short coming.  
With further research you may also find that Americans are unwilling to pay a higher price for a product with a longer warranty.  They may be more likely to save money up front and take their chances later, no amount of government regulation can change that kind of fundamental difference.  
Product warranties on coffee makers would fall under the economic umbrella of a business, not as an ethical concern.  Congressman Young's answer was correct.

Comment: GST is applied on top of the "carbon tax" (which isn't applied on carbon leakage from hydro dams etc. only fossil fuels) so this is a huge windfall for the federal government"s coffers.  "all carbon tax money stays in the province it was raised" is not true unless Ottawa also sends the extra GST back to the provinces too.

Also, the cap and trade is a floating market mechanism so making sure that each year is a certain price per ton is nearly impossible...this could be a big warm on national unity if the cap and trade provinces don't have the same price as the carbon tax province every year.

Comment: "Public Education" has not evolved logically. We are still stuck with an omnibus "See You in September" paradigm based on summers off to help the family with the harvest. Honestly, does everyone understand that this is the historical "logic" behind the US Public Education Calendar?
Assuming that increased student success is the desired outcome, there is absolutely NO reasonable and logical purpose to having EACH AND EVERY student REQUIRED to PHYSICALLY attend via CLASSROOM SEAT TIME through the hottest months of the year. 
Students in need of additional help should be required to attend year-'round school 52 weeks per year with no breaks until they become satisfactory.
Students who make satisfactory progress should be enrolled in courses September to June, with July and August for vacation because those are the hottest months.
Students who are exceptional should be allowed to attend half time for the "Three Rs" and be otherwise freed up to seek their gifts in music, art, STEM, etc.

Comment: I think the author overstates his position.  Saying somebody is a fighter doesn't demean those who don't win.  Weren't they fighters as well?  How do you lose if you don't first fight?

My parents both died of cancer and neither of them chose to fight it: my mother because it was was caught only a week before she died, and my father because he was satisfied with the life he'd enjoyed, and he was into his 80s.  He didn't want to spend his last days the object of sympathy.  He accepted it, as did my brother and I.

These choices are very personal and I find it unseemly to criticize someone for the choice that ultimately only they can make.

My dad didn't lose.  He just accepted it was his time and he had to die of something.  He didn't want to spend his last days hooked up to a dialysis machine.  I think he showed courage in his own way.  I would have liked to have held on to both of my parents but this is the way of life.  You live and then you die.  Is there anybody planning not to?

Comment: I'm certainly enjoying today's 4C dry mid-winter weather in Toronto, with more of the same on tap for the next few days. However, I'm not sure I agree with the definition of "mild" weather described in the article (18C to 30C). To me, mild, or comfortable, daytime highs range from 12C to 24C, although to a great extent this is dependent on the season. A high of 12C in June would be cold while it would be really nice in November. A high temperature over 24C, especially when combined with the summer humidity that's a virtual certainty in places like southern Ontario, is essentially hot weather in much of the country.

Better coverage, less cost, no need to choose between suicide and crushing medical bills. Under such a system, aid in dying would be less contentious.

I didn`t say it would be economic for them to finance the balance themselves, though I think they could do legally by law,.. bond for it, with authority granted by the feds when we bought it from Reagan, who was going to sell it to somebody for thirty million or so, even if all they wanted was to tear up the rails and sell them for the scrap value. It still deserves all the infrastructure links we can give it to take advantage of multiple port capabilities and CARGOES, and changing weather and geological conditions that frequently close and complicate rail and road travel from the southern ports of Seward and Whittier, both also vital to the state..

Comment: In my opinion, the Alaska health insurance market for people not on ACA subsidy or company health plan is not sustainable and is going in to a death spiral (so to speak). The higher the premiums, the less people signing up, the higher the premiums go to cover, the less people sign up and so forth until nobody signs up because it is too expensive.
I will admit I will become part of this spiral at the rates quoted to me.

I have a small business and I take home approx 120,000 per year before taxes. I employ 4 people. The decisions I make allow these employees to feed their families, have a roof over their heads, and go out to dinner when they want to, so in effect for this income, my decisions support about 15 people.
 Due to our income, and age the cheapest plan available last open enrollment for my wife and I was $3800.00 per month (no kidding). 

to be continued

Comment: It is a fallacy to assume that Canada is a big country and we can accommodate whoever wish to come here. We are big, that is true. But most of our land is unsuitable to human habitation. If you count only areas that are suitable for human habitation, Canada is actually a very small country, probably smaller than Haiti. That is why homes in Toronto and Vancouver have hit the million dollar mark. We can't even house our own people. How can we house the new arrivals?

Comment: OK Last post: The origination of the 12 hour 1/2 day started in Egypt.
